Award.AwardTitle: AMPS: Algebraic Geometry under Uncertainty for Power Flow Systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
The National Academy of Engineering has classified widespread electrification as one of the greatest engineering achievements of the 20th century, but a 2006 study estimated that the national annual cost of power interruptions was about $79 billion dollars. The power flow equations are at the heart of all tools used by power system engineers to maintain reliable, economically operated power systems. These equations have variability, and our team of engineers and mathematicians will address in this project how this affects their solutions.

These equations model the nonlinear relationship between voltages and active and reactive power injections in a power system and can be represented by multivariate quadratics. The goal now is to introduce uncertainty into the coefficients of the polynomials (the susceptances) and to investigate how their number of real solutions varies, bound it, and obtain practical algorithms for finding all these solutions under that uncertainty. The distribution of numbers of real solutions is known for general polynomial systems under assumptions such as that the coefficients are iid Gaussian but the power flow systems appear to have fewer real solutions than those results would predict. The group intends to generalize this work to our special systems, understand the phenomena, and then apply them to actual power systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The balance between supply and demand within electrical power grids is controled by the power flow equations. Much work therefore has gone into finding ways to find a (real-valued) solution in each instance, but we want to find all solutions (there are always finitely many), allowing more flexibility and robustness in choosing which solution to go with. Moreover, we have sought to gain a complete understanding of the solutions to the power flow equations, in particular of the distribution of numbers of solutions. Our plan was to explain why very few solutions are observed in practice, and ultimately to help in the monitoring and design of future grids, but in fact we have shown (rigorously for some small networks) that these systems of equations on average have more solutions than a corresponding random system of equations of the same size. This runs counter to what was believed by engineers in the field to date and is a surprising and significant result. Our techniques (derived from algebraic geometry) involve showing that for most grids the system can be reduced to one polynomial equation in one variable. This allows us to study the distribution of the number of real solutions very efficiently and finer information, similar to tools used in inverse kinematics for robot manipulators (and indeed our techniques can be applied there too). We have also trained engineering and mathematics PhD students in transdisciplinary approaches by introducing engineers to novel techniques of applied algebraic geometry and by introducing mathematicians to very interesting applications of their expertise. Several conference papers (mostly delivered by these PhD students) and a journal paper under preparation have ensued, and this work should feature in the PhD theses of at least three PhD students (2 in Math, 1 in ECE).
